head.title: National News Briefs; Steelworkers and Kaiser Reach a Settlement

hedline.hl1: National News Briefs; Steelworkers and Kaiser Reach a Settlement

abstract.p: Kaiser Aluminum and United Steelworkers of America settle 20-month labor dispute that resulted in lockout of 2,900 workers (S)

block.p: Kaiser Aluminum and the United Steelworkers of America yesterday settled one of the nation's longest labor disputes, a 20-month lockout of 2,900 workers.

The dispute focused on a Kaiser plan to contract out jobs, cut its work force and reduce health benefits. The dispute involved two plants in Spokane and others in Tacoma, Wash., Gramercy, La., and Newark, Ohio.
Kaiser Aluminum and the United Steelworkers of America yesterday settled one of the nation's longest labor disputes, a 20-month lockout of 2,900 workers.

The dispute focused on a Kaiser plan to contract out jobs, cut its work force and reduce health benefits. The dispute involved two plants in Spokane and others in Tacoma, Wash., Gramercy, La., and Newark, Ohio.
The strike began in September 1998, but when the union sought to end it in January 1999 Kaiser refused to take the unionized workers back without a settlement.

David Foster, the Northwest director of the steelworkers' union, said a new five-year contract placed limits on contracting out work. It also permits Kaiser to eliminate more than 500 jobs and gives the workers, who averaged $14 an hour, pay raises of $3.42 over five years.
